AssessmentItem.Content: The African elephant, the largest land animal now alive, is in danger of extinction (灭绝). The reasons are very similar to those in other cases of near-extinction: the beast is the source of a highly valued commodity -- in this case, ivory -- and the animal's habitat (居住地) is being more and more fenced in by human settlements. East African elephants are most immediately threatened because they are victims of an illegal trade in ivory. At the same time, a growing human population has forced all African elephants back into once remote parks, where elephant density has in many cases exceeded the natural food supply.

question.prompt: The author suggests that the causes of animal extinction are _________.

choices.choice: peculiar to each group of animals
dependent on the climate in which the animal lives
dependent on the size of the animal

question.prompt: Which of the following has most seriously affected the African elephant?
The East African elephant may become extinct sooner than other African elephants because of _________.
The major problem facing elephants forced to live in limited areas is the _________.

choices.choice: competition with other animals for space

AssessmentItem.Content:
Scientists know that there are two basic approaches to prolonging life. One approach is the (_elimination_) of the diseases that generally (_affect_) older people -- diseases such as cancer, heart attack and strokes. (_The other_) is the delay of the process of growing old and the (_4_) of the body. In recent years scientific researches have (_spent_) much time in the study of the process of aging.
They believe that (_6_) several years, they will develop the knowledge and the (_7_) to delay the aging process for ten to fifteen years. The (_result_) will be that more people will live longer, and more people will have healthful lives. At (_present_) scientists believe that (_10_) the right food, exercise, medical (_11_), and mental attitude, many people can live to (_be_) one hundred years old. Doctors who (_specialize_) in studies of problems of growing old are investigating (_why_) body cells (细胞) slow down and (_finally_) die. They feel that delaying this slowing down process could help put (_off_) death. In a number of American universities, scientists are (_studying_) the activity of cells, the effects of food and internal body temperature (_18_) aging. If their studies are (_successful_), the result should help to improve the quality of life for people in the next few years as (_well_) as increase the life duration of the next generation.

Who won the World Cup 1994 football game? What happened at the United Nations? How did the critics like the new play? (_Just when_) an event takes place, newspapers are on the streets (_to give_) the details. Wherever anything happens in the world, reporters are on the spot to (_gather_) the news. Newspapers have one basic (_4_), to get the news as quickly as possible from its source, from those who make it to those who want to (_know_) it. Radio, telegraph, television, and (_other_) inventions brought competition for newspapers. So did the development of magazines and other means of communication. (_However_), this competition merely spurred the newspapers on. They quickly made use of the newer and faster means of communication to improve the (_8_) and thus the efficiency of their own operations. Today more newspapers are (_printed_) and read than ever before. Competition also led newspapers to branch out into many other fields. Besides, keeping readers (_10_) of the latest news, today's newspapers (_educate_) and influence readers about politics and other important and serious matters. Newspapers influence readers' economic choices (_through_) advertising. Most newspapers depend on advertising for their very (_existance_). Newspapers are sold at a price that (_fails to cover_) even a small fraction of the cost of production. The main (_15_) of income for most newspapers is commercial advertising. The (_16_) in selling advertising depends on a newspaper's value to advertisers. This (_is measured_) in terms of circulation. How many people read the newspaper? Circulation depends (_much_) on the work of the circulation department and on the services or entertainment (_offered_) in a newspaper's pages. But for the most part, circulation depends on a newspaper's value to readers as a source of information (_20_) the community, city, country, state, nation, and world — and even outer space.
